Civil commitment is the coercing of individuals into mental health treatment because they've been found to be either a danger to themselves or to others, or are gravely disabled.

So if you find someone who's functioning so badly in the community that if you leave them alone they're likely to become dangerously ill or perhaps do violence to themselves or others, we in the United States and elsewhere coerce them into treatment.
And coercing someone into treatment requires the finding that their functioning level, that is that their behavior, is such that if they continue it they will be in dire straits.
That is that they're not acting the way that you'd expect others to respond to things in the environment.
When the economy gets worse, it turns out that more of these civil commitments are done.
More people are coerced into treatment than is otherwise the case.
But perhaps more importantly, it's also the case that when the economy is worse, the level of functioning of these people who are coerced into treatment is actually better.
That is, it appears that people who would function and be left alone pretty much when the economy is going well actually get coerced into treatment when the economy is worse.

And this finding is consistent with a long tradition in research looking at what's called the frustration-aggression theory, which is that when the economy contracts, people become frustrated.

In the contemporary world, thank goodness, we don't lynch people any longer, but it's still the case, for example, that African-American males are coerced into treatment much more frequently when the economy contracts, and they actually are better-functioning males, suggesting that our tolerance for this group of persons actually goes down, and we aggress against them in more societally acceptable ways, in which we report them to the police.
